Award.AwardTitle: A new era for stellar ages with older benchmark star clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
Jason Curtis is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at Columbia University. Using observations from ground- and space-based telescopes, Curtis will study the relationship between magnetic activity and rotation of stars and how this relationship changes with age. Because stars change very little over most of their lifetimes, determining their ages is challenging, but it is essential for understanding planets around other stars. Curtis will also conduct an annual data science workshop in basic computing, statistical, and data analysis methods for the participants of a program that prepares underrepresented minority students for graduate school; and he will serve as research mentor to one student from this program.

The proposed research will address stellar ages with a two-pronged observational program: (1) Curtis will analyze rotation data for 3 GYr stars down to 0.39 Solar masses from his ongoing survey of Ruprecht 147 with the Kepler space telescope, to calibrate gyrochronology relations at low mass at older ages. The Kepler survey also will yield asteroseismic measurements for dwarfs in this benchmark star cluster. Comparison of the red giant asteroseismic masses and FGK dwarf rotation sequences between the similarly aged NGC 6819 and R147 will demonstrate the precision and relative accuracy of each method; and (2) Curtis has initiated a large chromospheric activity survey of middle-aged star clusters with the Multi Mirror Telescope (MMT) to establish an activity-age relationship that is applicable to K dwarfs. As part of his education plan, Curtis will be integrated into Columbia University's Bridge to the Ph.D Program to (1) conduct an annual data science workshop series that will instruct Bridge Participants in basic computing, statistical methods, and data analysis with Python (materials from the workshop will be incorporated in a Data Science Primer for Astronomers); and (2) supervise one Bridge Participant's research, which will focus on measuring 3 GYr M dwarf rotation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: 

Sun-like stars change very little during their long main-sequence lifetimes, making their ages one of their most challenging properties to determine. However, knowing stellar ages is essential in this era of precision astrophysics. Our current inability to provide confident ages for these stars limits our understanding of the Milky Way's star-formation and chemical-enrichment histories, for example. But it is the recent explosion of interest in finding exoplanets and determining their habitability that has given the question of how to determine the ages of low-mass stars a new urgency, because potentially habitable, Earth-like planets are most likely to be discovered orbiting these stars. To guide future exploration, we need to infer with confidence the ages of these stars.  

Fortunately, low-mass stars do have built-in clocks: they spin down over time via magnetic braking, and this coupling of a star's magnetic fields and its rotation creates a feedback loop which causes rotation rates for a given stellar mass to converge after a period of time that depends on that mass (e.g., for young twins of the Sun, it only takes 100 Myr). This process forms a tightly correlated relationship between stellar mass and spin rate, and this convergence underlies the "gyrochronology" age-dating technique. Standard models assume stars spin down continuously after, so precise ages should be revealed from knowledge of a star's mass and spin rate. 

The calibration of gyrochronology requires stars with known rotation rates and age. The best benchmarks are the Sun and star clusters. Dr. Curtis measured stellar rotation for 171 low-mass stars in the 1-billion-year-old cluster NGC 6811 with Kepler data (Curtis et al. 2019a) and for 34 stars in the 3-billion-year-old cluster Ruprecht 147 with K2 data (Curtis et al. 2020, submitted). Surprisingly, these data demonstrate that stars do not spin down continuously, but instead temporarily stall after converging on the slow sequence (this is illustrated in the figure included with this report). Furthermore, based on where the rotation period sequences for the various clusters overlap, the duration of this epoch of stalled spin-down increases toward lower stellar masses. For example, these data show that a star with 60% of the Sun's mass remains stalled for one billion years. Extrapolating the relationship down to 50% of the Sun's mass suggests that such stars remain stalled for two billion years. The steep mass dependence means that this phenomenon might present a big obstacle for age-dating even lower-mass stars with rotation. Unfortunately, the cluster data do not yet extend to these lower masses to test this hypothesis. Exploring the physical cause of the stalling phenomenon will be the focus of the fellow's continuing research into stellar age-dating and gyrochronology.

After completing the study of NGC 6811, Dr. Curtis investigated the age of the newly discovered Pisces-Eridanus stellar stream (Psc-Eri). This "stream" is composed of hundreds of stars spread out in a narrow path stretching across one-third of the sky and spanning 400 parsecs in space. Discovered by Meignast et al. (2019), they claimed an age of 1 billion years for the stream. Given its close proximity to Earth compared to the NGC 6811 cluster, this would enable a careful examination of the magnetic behaviors of the low mass stars, which could offer clues into the physical cause of the stalled braking phenomenon. Dr. Curtis used data from NASA's new Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) to measure how fast its star are spinning. By comparing the rotation periods for 101 Psc-Eri members to those for benchmark star clusters with a range of ages, Dr. Curtis concluded that it is only 120 million years old, much younger than originally thought. Although this is far too young to be useful for exploring the stalled braking phenomenon, it does make Psc-Eri an exciting new reservoir for young stars with precisely known ages. Indeed, Curtis et al. (2019b) announced that a candidate multi-planet system had already been found by TESS orbiting a young Sun-like star in Pisces-Eridanus. Such benchmark planets are needed for exploring how the high-energy radiation environments of young stars might impact planet formation.

Broader Impacts:

Dr. Curtis supported Columbia University's Bridge to the Ph.D. in STEM Program, which seeks to increase the number of underrepresented scholars entering Ph.D. programs. During the two-year program, the scholars complete research, coursework, and professional development workshops. Dr. Curtis mentored the astrophysics scholars in the program. He met regularly with scholars to discuss their progress and challenges, and provided one-on-one instruction on computer programming, data analysis techniques, academic paper writing, oral presentation preparation, and advised them on career planning and applying to graduate programs.
